qas.question: Why might two plants be similar but not actually be in the same group?
How can two different plants acquire the same traits?
What traits show a shared ancestry?
How are common ancestries represented for plant families?

context: Judging relationships based on shared characters requires care, since plants may resemble one another through <a0_0>convergent evolution<a0_0/> in which characters have <a1_0>arisen independently<a1_0/>. Some euphorbias have leafless, rounded bodies adapted to water conservation similar to those of globular cacti, but characters such as the structure of their flowers make it clear that the two groups are not closely related. The cladistic method takes a systematic approach to characters, distinguishing between those that carry no information about shared evolutionary history – such as those evolved separately in different groups (homoplasies) or those left over from ancestors (plesiomorphies) – and derived characters, which have been passed down from innovations in a shared ancestor (apomorphies). Only <a2_0>derived characters<a2_0/>, such as the spine-producing areoles of cacti, provide evidence for descent from a common ancestor. The results of cladistic analyses are expressed as cladograms: <a3_0>tree-like diagrams<a3_0/> showing the pattern of evolutionary branching and descent.
